Title:
Diaporthe species associated with peach constriction canker
in China, with two new species described
Keywords:
constriction canker, Diaporthe, multi-gene phylogeny,
Prunus persica, taxonomy, two new taxa
Abstract:
Diaporthe species infect a wide range of plants, and
living live in vivo as endophytes, saprobes or pathogens, whereas these
species in peach plantstrees are far less characterized. In this study,
52 Diaporthe strains were isolated from 27 infected bud samples of peach
trees from Fujian Province, China, showing constriction canker symptoms
in Fujian Province, China. Phylogenetic analyses based on five loci,
including internal transcribed spacer of the ribosomal DNA (ITS),
translation elongation factor 1-α (TEF), ß-tubulin (TUB), histone (HIS),
and calmodulin (CAL) gene regions, coupled with morphology revealed
seven species associated with the disease, including five known species
(D. caryae, D. cercidis, D. eres, D. hongkongensis, and D. unshiuensis).
In this study, two novel species (D. jinxiu and D. zaofenghuang) as
referring to the host varieties are also introduced. This study
represents the first characterization of these Diaporthe species related
to the peach constriction canker in China, contributes useful data for
practicable disease management.
